title: New North Church, Edinburgh
author: Livingston, Josiah.
snippet: Some arrangement hadbeen made when the alteration on St Giles' was fixedon whereby a new church was to be built for Mr Bruce,and for this purpose, while we were in the MethodistChapel, there was a grand ceremonial laying the foundation on the Castlehill; but, failing Mr Bruce, thenew church and our old parish were to go to the congregation of the Tolbooth Church, and a new parishwas to be cut out for the New North, which wagafterwards fixed to be in the High Street, betweenSt Giles' and the Tron Church on the north, and theCowgate on the south. But when Mr Bruce left usnot a stone had been built of our new church nowcalled the Assembly Hall, and the congregation wastold just to remain where it was in Brighton Street. Our parish was taken from us by the Tolbooth people,while the new one was not fixed for us for some time,so in addition to wanting minister, precentor, bedrell,and great part of the congregation, we were minus aparish also.

title: New North Church, Edinburgh
author: Livingston, Josiah.
snippet: When we thought we had trespassed long enoughon the hospitality of our Congregationalist friends,in November 1843 we resumed possession of our oldmeeting-house in Brighton Street, the residuary congregation having been transferred to West St Giles'. We continued there till the church was sold over ourheads, and we found refuge in Dr Ritchie's church inthe Potterrow in 1846, and were there till our newchurch in Forrest Road was opened in June 1848.

title: New North Church, Edinburgh
author: Livingston, Josiah.
snippet: But there came an entire change over the NewNorth. The Town Council had discovered that therent paid for the Methodist Chapel was too high, andthey hired for us a big cold chapel in Brighton Street,which was empty at the time. To this we shifted in1836, and we did not like the change.

title: New North Church, Edinburgh
author: Livingston, Josiah.
snippet: Thedraft is in the handwriting of the young manwhom Mr Livingston allowed to assist him, andwas adopted without one word of alteration. Whenthe time of action came, and we had to leave theEstablishment in May 1843, we went almost as acongregation, leaving the church in Brighton Street. We were hospitably entertained by the IndependentCongregation in Argyle Square, the minister of which,Dr Alexander, and his people generously alteringtheir hours of worship so as to share the day with us.

title: New North Church, Edinburgh
author: Livingston, Josiah.
snippet: by the Disruption, and the excitement from it andthis subsequent work told on his nervous system,so that he became seriously ill in the Septemberof 1844, and continued unfit for service till November1845. We were worshipping in Brighton Street,when he preached his first sermon after his restoration from the text, "Thanks be unto God for Hisunspeakable gift." During his illness we receivedmost willing and much appreciated help from manyof the best ministers of the church, which leads me tospeak of the kind of assistance which Mr Browndrew to himself and his people.
